items.title: Future mesoscale horizontal stirring in polar oceans intensified by sea ice decline
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 05 November 2025

Future mesoscale horizontal stirring in polar oceans intensified by sea ice decline
                    Gyuseok Yi 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-8812-92251,2, June-Yi Lee 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-3986-97531,2,3, Eun Young Kwon 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-9165-41111,2, Sun-Seon Lee 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-7403-64851,4, Myeong-Hyeon Kim 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0009-0008-5973-868X1,2, Wonsun Park 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-6345-84281,2, Karl Stein 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-2432-18671,4 & …Axel Timmermann 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-0657-29691,4 Show authors

Nature Climate Change

(2025)Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate and Earth system modellingPhysical oceanography

AbstractMesoscale horizontal stirring (MHS) is ubiquitous in the oceans, influencing heat and carbon transport, phytoplankton blooms and fish larvae dispersal. The current generation of Earth system models lacks sufficient resolution to properly resolve MHS-relevant small-scale phenomena, such as oceanic mesoscale eddies, leaving it largely unknown how MHS will change in response to greenhouse warming. Here we determine how CO2 doubling and quadrupling will change the surface MHS statistics in Community Earth System Model simulations with 1/10-degree ocean resolution. MHS is analysed using the finite-size Lyapunov exponent, a Lagrangian diagnostic that measures the separation of close trajectories. Projected increases in MHS are expected in the Arctic Ocean and coastal Antarctic regions, driven by enhanced time-mean ocean flow and turbulence which predominantly result from sea ice reduction. The enhanced horizontal stirring in polar oceans implies substantial yet uncertain consequences for tracer transport, nutrient supply and ecosystems under higher CO2 conditions.

MainStirring is a turbulent process that deforms and stretches fluid elements into elongated filaments, thereby dispersing fluid properties and generating sharp gradients1,2. These gradients are smoothed by diffusion and, together with stirring, this leads to irreversible homogenization (mixing). In the ocean, where horizontal velocities dominate over vertical ones across most scales, mesoscale horizontal stirring (MHS) is the primary dynamical process. MHS is closely linked to mesoscale features such as eddies, meanders, fronts and filaments, which span tens to hundreds of kilometres and persist for days to months. It plays a pivotal role in regulating the transport of heat, carbon and other tracers3,4,5,6, phytoplankton blooms7,8,9,10, the dispersal of larvae and fish eggs11,12 and broader ecosystem interactions13,14,15.Given the wide-ranging impacts of MHS, understanding how MHS will respond to future climate change is particularly important in high latitudes, where warming is most strongly amplified. Recently, rapid sea ice decline due to greenhouse warming16,17,18 has driven major environmental changes in polar oceans, altering ocean temperature, salinity and surface momentum flux19,20,21,22, with potential consequences for diverse physical and biological processes23,24,25. Recent studies using state-of-the-art climate models have reported marked changes in upper-ocean circulation22 and a substantial increase in eddy activity26 in the Arctic under warming scenarios. Notably, a kilometre-scale high-resolution simulation showed a threefold increase in eddy kinetic energy (EKE) in the upper Arctic Ocean under a 4 °C-warmer climate, associated with enhanced baroclinic instability driven by sea ice loss26. Such dynamical changes are expected to markedly influence MHS. While a Lagrangian-based network theory study linked increased kinetic energy to stronger horizontal stirring in the Mediterranean under a warmer climate27, comparable analyses in polar regions are still lacking. Addressing this gap is crucial to improve understanding of oceanic responses to greenhouse warming in the most rapidly changing regions of the world.Here focusing on the polar oceans, we explore spatiotemporal changes in surface MHS under varying CO2 conditions. To characterize and assess changes in MHS, we use the finite-size Lyapunov exponent (FSLE)28,29, a Lagrangian diagnostic which measures the continuous exponential rate of separation between nearby particle trajectories, indicating how quickly a patch of passive tracers is stretched (Methods). The FSLE provides spatially and temporally resolved estimates of transport and mixing, revealing fine-scale features such as filaments and spirals that are often overlooked by Eulerian methods29,30. In this study, FSLE is calculated as the time-based growth rate of separation from an initial distance (δ0) to a final distance (δf), defined as a tenfold increase. To target mesoscale structure, δ0 and δf are set to 0.1° and 1.0°, respectively. This choice of δ0 aligns with the 0.1° horizontal resolution of the ocean model, while δf is set to a scale comparable to that used in previous studies28,31 for consistency (see Supplementary Information for δ0–δf sensitivity tests). The FSLE technique has been successfully applied to identify complex spatial and seasonal patterns of surface MHS in both the Mediterranean and global ocean under present-day conditions28,31.To investigate how future greenhouse warming affects MHS, we analyse idealized century-long time-slice simulations conducted using the fully coupled ultra-high-resolution Community Earth System Model v.1.2.2 (CESM-UHR)32,33,34, with horizontal resolution of 0.25° for the atmosphere and 0.1° for the ocean. Notably, in the Arctic the ocean model uses a tripolar grid with 2.5-km eddy-permitting resolution. The three experiments34,35,36,37 use constant atmospheric CO2 concentrations of 367 ppm (present-day, PD), 734 ppm (2 × CO2) and 1,468 ppm (4 × CO2) (Methods). Daily FSLEs, a measure of MHS, are analysed at each grid point over 10 years in each simulation. This approach enables evaluation of MHS changes under different CO2 conditions within a fully coupled ocean–sea ice–atmosphere framework. FSLEs from the CESM-UHR PD simulation closely match ocean reanalysis38 in both magnitude and spatial distribution (Supplementary Information), supporting the suitability of the model for this study.Surface MHS changes in polar oceansWe first examine surface MHS responses to varying CO2 forcing in the polar oceans by comparing daily FSLE snapshots at 15-m depth from the PD and 4 × CO2 simulations (Fig. 1a–d). The snapshots correspond approximately to the period of maximum sea ice extent—the vernal equinox (20 March) in the Northern Hemisphere and the autumnal equinox (22 September) in the Southern Hemisphere. At the vernal equinox of the first analysis year, Arctic FSLE fields show a marked intensification under 4 × CO2 relative to PD (Fig. 1a,b and Supplementary Video 1). FSLEs appear as filaments marked by local maxima, highlighting rapid separation of adjacent flow trajectories, especially at the edges of strong currents, vortices and meanders. Corresponding current speed snapshots (Fig. 1e,f) show that FSLE increases are most pronounced along major currents (for example, the Beaufort Gyre and Transpolar Drift Stream) and vortex boundaries across the Arctic. The greater prevalence of FSLE filaments under 4 × CO2 indicates marked MHS intensification driven by stronger mesoscale activity and mean flow. This intensification is probably attributable to a combination of factors, including increased momentum transfer to the surface ocean by wind in the absence of sea ice39 (Fig. 1i,j), enhanced eddy generation due to stronger upper-ocean baroclinic instability26 and reduced sea ice friction which would otherwise damp eddies40.Fig. 1: FSLE, current speed and sea ice concentration in the polar oceans under PD and 4 × CO2 conditions.a,b,e,f,i,j, Arctic Ocean snapshots of FSLE at 15-m depth (a,b), current speed (log scale) at 15-m depth (e,f) and sea ice concentration (i,j) from the PD (a,e,i) and 4 × CO2 (b,f,j) simulations at the vernal equinox (20 March) of the first analysed year (model year 130 for PD and model year 160 for 4 × CO2). c,d,g,h,k,l, Southern Ocean snapshots of FSLE at 15-m depth (c,d), current speed (log scale) at 15-m depth (g,h) and sea ice concentration (k,l) from the PD (c,g,k) and 4 × CO2 (d,h,l) simulations at the autumnal equinox (22 September). Credit: Basemaps from NASA Visible Earth (https://visibleearth.nasa.gov).Source dataFull size imageIn the Southern Ocean, daily FSLE snapshots at the autumnal equinox of the first year show a marked increase along the Antarctic periphery under 4 × CO2 relative to PD (Fig. 1c,d and Supplementary Video 2), coinciding with coastal regions where the Antarctic slope current (ASC) strengthens (Fig. 1g,h). As sea ice decreases in 4 × CO2 (Fig. 1k,l), the ASC within ~200 km of the coast strengthens by about 60% relative to PD. Similar changes are evident at subsurface depths of 75 m and 155 m (Extended Data Fig. 1), supporting the robustness of the 15-m results—the primary focus of this study. This depth minimizes direct wind and sea ice influences while capturing surface MHS patterns relevant to climate and ecosystems28.Probability density functions (PDFs) of daily FSLEs for each decade show a pronounced increase in polar ocean FSLEs. Surface ocean FSLEs generally follow a long-tailed, right-skewed distribution31,41,42, consistent with our results (Fig. 2). In warmer climates, the PDFs shift towards higher values, with the median moving rightwards, low values becoming less frequent and high values more common—changes that are statistically significant at the 95% level (Fig. 2a–c). This indicates stronger MHS, which accelerates the separation of nearby trajectories over broader areas and shortens the timescale to reach a 1.0° separation. The Arctic (Fig. 2a) shows most of its change from PD to 2 × CO2, with little further shift at 4 × CO2, reflecting CESM-UHR projections of a sharp sea ice decline under 2 × CO2 and near ice-free conditions for most of the year under 4 × CO2 (Extended Data Fig. 2a). The Southern Ocean (Fig. 2b) shows a modest PDF shift from PD to 2 × CO2, followed by a larger change from 2 × CO2 to 4 × CO2. This pattern differs from the gradual decline in sea ice extent observed throughout the Southern Ocean (Extended Data Fig. 2b) but aligns more closely with the progressive PDF changes seen in the Antarctic coastal region (Fig. 2c). Changes in the polar oceans are markedly greater than the minor shifts in the rest of the global ocean, where PDFs move only slightly rightwards, probably reflecting a balance between regional increases and decreases (Fig. 2d and Supplementary Information).Fig. 2: PDFs of FSLEs for the Arctic Ocean, the Southern Ocean, the Antarctic coastal region and non-polar oceans under different CO2 conditions.a–d, FSLE PDFs from PD (blue), 2 × CO2 (orange) and 4 × CO2 (red) in the yellow-highlighted regions: the Arctic Ocean (66.5–90° N) (a), the Southern Ocean (60–90° S) (b), the Antarctic coastal region (within about 200 km of the Antarctic coastline) (c) and the non-polar oceans (60° S–66.5° N) (d). Vertical solid lines denote medians. Wilcoxon rank-sum tests indicate significant differences (P < 0.05) between PD and both 2 × CO2 and 4 × CO2 in a–d. Credit: Inset basemaps from NASA Visible Earth (https://visibleearth.nasa.gov).Source dataFull size imageA comparison of decadal mean FSLE (\({\overline{{\mathrm{FSLE}}}}_{{\mathrm{h}}}\)) between PD and 4 × CO2 confirms a robust increase in surface MHS in response to greenhouse warming (Fig. 3a–d and Extended Data Fig. 3a–d), consistent with the snapshot comparison. This increase is also evident in 2-year means at 15-m, 75-m and 155-m depths, with decreasing magnitude at greater depths but similar spatial patterns (Supplementary Fig. 1). FSLEs are averaged using the harmonic mean (denoted by the subscript h), which is more appropriate for averaging rates of increase (Methods). The long-term mean FSLE changes reflect a combination of narrow features related to mean currents and broader turbulent structures driven by eddy activity (Fig. 3 and Extended Data Fig. 3).Fig. 3: FSLE, MKE and EKE under different CO2 conditions.a,b,e,f,i,j, The 10-year means at 15-m depth in the Arctic Ocean: FSLE (harmonic mean) (a,b) and square roots of the 10-year means of MKE (e,f) and EKE (i,j), for PD (a,e,i) and 4 × CO2 (b,f,j). c,d,g,h,k,l, The 10-year means at 15-m depth in the Southern Ocean: FSLE (harmonic mean) (c,d) and square roots of the 10-year means of MKE (g,h) and EKE (k,l), for PD (c,g,k) and 4 × CO2 (d,h,l). Credit: Basemaps from NASA Visible Earth (https://visibleearth.nasa.gov).Source dataFull size imageThese dramatic FSLE changes are also clearly reflected in the time series of domain-averaged FSLEs under PD, 2 × CO2 and 4 × CO2 simulations (Extended Data Fig. 4). In the Arctic, projected FSLE increases far exceed the amplitude of the PD annual cycle, which weakens under elevated CO2 (Extended Data Fig. 4a). This probably reflects the substantial loss of sea ice (dashed lines in Extended Data Fig. 4a) that drives seasonal variability in the present climate. As a result, interannual variability is expected to become more prominent. In contrast, the Southern Ocean exhibits a gradual FSLE increase along the Antarctic coast while the annual cycle remains relatively stable under warming (Extended Data Fig. 4b).Mean flow and eddy roles in MHS changesTo elucidate the relative contributions of mean flow and eddies to MHS changes, we analyse mean kinetic energy (MKE) and EKE, widely used Eulerian diagnostics31,42. While increases in horizontal stirring have been linked to MKE and EKE in the Mediterranean27, their roles in projected FSLE changes over polar oceans remain unexplored. Here MKE and EKE are estimated by decomposing daily horizontal velocities (\(u\), \(v\)) into mean components (\(\bar{u}\), \(\bar{v}\)) and eddy components (\({u}^{{\prime} }\), \({v}^{{\prime} }\)) using a 300-day high-pass filter43 (Methods). In both PD and 4 × CO2 simulations, decadal mean MKE exhibits localized maxima in narrow current bands (Fig. 3e–h), whereas EKE shows broader, more diffuse structures (Fig. 3i–l). The FSLE fields capture features of both but more closely resemble EKE patterns (Fig. 3a–d). Projected FSLE changes qualitatively follow changes in both MKE and EKE, as evident in PD versus 2 × CO2 and 4 × CO2 differences (Extended Data Fig. 3). For a quantitative assessment, we compute spatial correlations between decadal mean FSLEs and the square roots of the corresponding decadal mean MKE, EKE and total kinetic energy (TKE) at each grid point in the PD simulation (\({\overline{{\rm{FSLE}}}}_{{\mathrm{h}}}\) ~ \(\sqrt{\overline{{\mathrm{MKE}}}}\), \(\sqrt{\overline{{\mathrm{EKE}}}}\) and \(\sqrt{\overline{{\mathrm{TKE}}}}\); Extended Data Fig. 5a–f). FSLEs in polar oceans correlate more strongly with EKE than with MKE, consistent with previous findings27. The FSLE–TKE relationship is stronger in the Arctic but slightly weaker in the Southern Ocean, relative to EKE. For changes from PD to 4 × CO2 (\(\Delta {\overline{\mathrm{FSLE}}}_{{\mathrm{h}}}\) ~ \(\Delta \sqrt{\overline{\mathrm{MKE}}}\), \(\Delta \sqrt{\overline{{\mathrm{EKE}}}}\) and \(\Delta \sqrt{\overline{\mathrm{TKE}}}\); Extended Data Fig. 5g–l), FSLE changes correlate most strongly with TKE in both polar oceans, followed by EKE and MKE. The same ranking holds for 2 × CO2 minus PD, except in the Arctic where the FSLE–EKE correlation marginally exceeds the FSLE–TKE correlation (Supplementary Fig. 2). Overall, these results suggest that polar MHS intensification is driven predominantly by the increase in total current speed, reflecting combined mean and eddy contributions2.To clarify the respective roles of mean flow and eddies in shaping MHS, we performed additional FSLE calculations excluding either component. Specifically, we computed FSLE fields based solely on the mean flow (FSLEm) and solely on the eddy field (FSLEe) (Supplementary Videos 3 and 4), using a 300-day high-pass filter for velocity decomposition, consistent with earlier methodology. FSLEm exhibits sharper, more elongated filaments, highlighting organized vortices and meanders on larger spatial scales—an imprint of the slowly evolving structure of the mean flow. In contrast, FSLEe appears more chaotic and diffuse, closely resembling the full FSLE field (rows 1 and 3 of Extended Data Fig. 6). This contrast is also evident in the 2-year means (\({\overline{{\mathrm{FSLE}}}}_{{\mathrm{h}}}\), \({\overline{{{\mathrm{FSLE}}}^{{\mathrm{m}}}}}_{{\mathrm{h}}}\) and \({\overline{{{\mathrm{FSLE}}}^{{\mathrm{e}}}}}_{{\mathrm{h}}}\)): FSLEm shows localized high values, whereas FSLEe develops more uniformly, mirroring the spatial distribution of the full FSLE mean (rows 2 and 4 of Extended Data Fig. 6). Spatial correlations between FSLE and FSLEe (FSLEm) are 0.81 (0.61) in the Arctic and 0.84 (0.70) in the Southern Ocean (Supplementary Fig. 3), showing that mesoscale turbulence is the dominant driver of MHS, while persistent mean structures such as currents and perennial meanders also contribute locally.Potential drivers of surface MHS changesAs the previous section established a strong link between FSLE and TKE, understanding surface MHS changes requires examining both mean flow and eddies, along with their environmental drivers. In the Arctic, the most prominent driver under elevated CO2 is substantial sea ice loss, evident in the pronounced reduction of mean sea ice extent during the peak sea ice season (February–April) (Fig. 4a–c). Relative to PD, sea ice extent decreases by 62.4% under 2 × CO2 and by 92.8% under 4 × CO2. This sea ice loss leads to a substantial alteration in the long-term wind stress pattern (Fig. 4d–f) and an increase in wind stress magnitude (Extended Data Fig. 7). Wind stress here refers to the total ocean stress (\({\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{ocn}}\)), combining air–ocean (\({\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{ao}}\)) and ice–ocean (\({\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{io}}\)) components. Under PD, the wind stress pattern is spatially heterogeneous (Fig. 4d), but shifts to a more homogeneous and intensified anticyclonic pattern across the Arctic Ocean under 2 × CO2 and 4 × CO2 (Fig. 4e,f). Given the key role of anticyclonic wind stress in driving Arctic current systems (the Beaufort Gyre and Transpolar Drift Stream)44,45 and enhancing eddy activity22,25, this shift may be a primary driver of MHS intensification in the CO2-enriched world.Fig. 4: Sea ice concentration, wind stress curl and surface geostrophic current in the Arctic Ocean under different CO2 conditions.a–i, The 10-year means of the February–April peak sea ice season (FMA) sea ice concentration (a–c), wind stress curl (d–f) and surface geostrophic current (g–i) are shown for the PD (a,d,g), 2 × CO2 (b,e,h) and 4 × CO2 (c,f,i) conditions. In a–c, the lime-coloured contour lines represent the boundary of sea ice extent (sea ice concentration of 15%). In g–i, the magnitude is represented using shading (arrows for currents exceeding 0.05 m s−1). Sea ice concentration is the result of the sea ice component, while wind stress is an outcome of the ocean component. The mean sea ice extent in the Arctic Ocean during FMA has decreased by 62.4% (from 12.42 million km2 to 4.67 million km2) in the 2 × CO2 conditions (b) and 92.8% (from 12.42 million km2 to 0.89 million km2) in the 4 × CO2 conditions (c), relative to PD.Source dataFull size imageWind stress magnitude changes due to sea ice loss are assessed through projected changes in the momentum transfer rate from the atmosphere and sea ice to the ocean (Extended Data Fig. 7). Over sea ice-covered areas, \({\vec{\tau}}_{\mathrm{ocn}}\) is the sum of \((1-A){\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{ao}}\) and \(A{\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{io}}\), with A representing the sea ice fraction used as a weighting factor22,46. The contribution of each component to momentum transfer is evaluated separately. In CESM-UHR results, the annual mean momentum transfer rate by \({\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{ocn}}\) increases by 5.42% (2 × CO2) and 4.54% (4 × CO2) relative to PD (Extended Data Fig. 7a). Although these increases are modest compared with the extent of sea ice loss, a pronounced rise in \({\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{ao}}\)-driven momentum transfer—especially with strong seasonality—is projected (Extended Data Fig. 7b), while \({\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{io}}\) contributions decline (Extended Data Fig. 7c; see Methods for further scaling analysis). These changes suggest that enhanced wind stress over ice-free areas may also contribute to surface MHS intensification.Consequently, the Arctic Ocean exhibits intensified surface geostrophic currents (Fig. 4g–i) and strengthened MHS. Projected sea surface height (SSH) changes, from which these currents are derived, correspond well with Ekman transport shifts (Extended Data Fig. 8). Under both 2 × CO2 and 4 × CO2, wind stress enhances Ekman transport from the Chukchi and East Siberian Seas towards the central Arctic, while reducing transport from the Eurasian Basin towards the Canada Basin and the east coast of Greenland (Extended Data Fig. 8a–c). These shifts expand the high SSH region—formerly confined to the Canada Basin in PD—into the Eurasian Basin (Extended Data Fig. 8d–f). As a result, the Transpolar Drift Stream, flowing along the Lomonosov Ridge in PD, is projected to intensify and shift towards the Barents-Kara Sea (Fig. 4g–i). These sea ice-driven changes align with recent studies25,26, supporting their role in Arctic MHS intensification.In the Southern Ocean, FSLE increases under warming are most pronounced along the Antarctic periphery, where the westward ASC flows (Fig. 3c,d). This region features strong easterly surface winds (Extended Data Fig. 9a) that drive Ekman transport towards the coast, elevating SSH and inducing a meridional (cross-shore) pressure gradient that drives the westward geostrophic ASC47,48,49. While previous modelling study suggests that a poleward shift of westerlies may weaken near-shore easterlies and thus the ASC and Ekman downwelling50, CESM-UHR simulations under 2 × CO2 and 4 × CO2 show only modest changes in easterlies (Extended Data Fig. 9b,c), yet project substantial ASC intensification. This intensification is linked to substantial sea ice loss (Fig. 5a–c) and surface density reductions along the Antarctic coast (Fig. 5d–f), primarily due to freshening rather than warming (Extended Data Fig. 9d–i). The resulting enhanced cross-shore density gradient strengthens surface geostrophic currents (Fig. 5g–i), effectively compensating for the slightly weakened zonal wind (Extended Data Fig. 9a–c). These results align with a recent study51 which linked ASC intensification under doubled CO2 to enhanced cross-shore density gradients driven by coastal freshening.Fig. 5: Sea ice concentration, potential density and surface geostrophic current in the Southern Ocean under different CO2 conditions.a–i, The 10-year means of August–October peak sea ice season (ASO) sea ice concentration (a–c), potential density (15-m depth) (d–f) and surface geostrophic current (g–i) are shown for the PD (a,d,g), 2 × CO2 (b,e,h) and 4 × CO2 (c,f,i) conditions. In a–c, the lime-coloured contour lines represent the boundary of sea ice extent (sea ice concentration of 15%). In g–i, the magnitude is represented using shading (arrows for currents exceeding 0.05 m s−1). The mean sea ice extent in the Southern Ocean during ASO has decreased by 19.1% (from 11.63 million km2 to 9.41 million km2) in the 2 × CO2 conditions (b) and 39.6% (from 11.63 million km2 to 7.02 million km2) in the 4 × CO2 conditions (c), relative to PD.Source dataFull size imageBeyond sea ice loss, coastal freshening is further influenced by changes in surface freshwater fluxes—particularly river and ice runoff (from the land component) and precipitation exceeding evaporation. In CESM-UHR, the dominant driver is meltwater flux from sea ice loss (Extended Data Fig. 10), interpreted as reduced brine rejection. This contrasts with the previous study51, which attributed the freshening mainly to precipitation and runoff. Our findings highlight the stronger role of sea ice loss (Extended Data Fig. 10b), suggesting that further investigation is needed.DiscussionThis study uses a Lagrangian-based FSLE to characterize surface MHS in CESM-UHR simulations, focusing on the polar oceans with supplementary analyses for other regions (Fig. 6 and Supplementary Information). Simulations project substantial polar MHS strengthening under greenhouse warming, driven by intensified surface currents from both mean flow and eddies, represented as MKE and EKE (Fig. 6). In the Arctic, sea ice loss enhances MHS through wind stress changes; in the Southern Ocean, it induces coastal freshening that strengthens the ASC and, in turn, MHS. The PD simulation underestimates sea ice extent (Extended Data Fig. 2), probably underestimating Arctic MHS change. Antarctic sea ice projections are more reliable; however, the model does not include ice sheet dynamics. The additional meltwater flux from ice sheets and shelves could further strengthen the ASC52, highlighting the need to investigate cryospheric impacts in future studies.Fig. 6: Changes in the global spatial distribution of surface ocean FSLE, MKE and EKE.a–c, Global distributions of the 10-year mean FSLE (harmonic mean) (a), MKE (b) and EKE (c) at 15-m depth from the PD simulation, with b and c shown as square roots. d,g, Differences in mean FSLE between PD and 2 × CO2 (d) and PD and 4 × CO2 (g). e,f,h,i, Differences in the square roots of mean MKE (e,h) and EKE (f,i), for 2 × CO2 minus PD (e,f) and 4 × CO2 minus PD (h,i). Credit: Basemaps from NASA Visible Earth (https://visibleearth.nasa.gov).Source dataFull size imageWhile we examined how surface MHS may respond to greenhouse warming, its consequent impacts on marine environments and ecosystems remain uncertain. Strengthened MHS in polar regions can reshape heat, carbon and tracer transport by modifying the relative contributions of mean circulation, Ekman transport and mesoscale eddy processes4,5. Moreover, MHS influences fine-scale vertical motions that regulate nutrient transport and shape phytoplankton distributions8,9,10,53,54. It can enhance production through submesoscale upwelling, but also suppress it by exporting nutrients offshore, as shown in coastal upwelling systems55. Yet, region-specific knowledge of how MHS controls nutrient supply and ecosystems under future climates remains limited, highlighting the need for further investigation. Such knowledge is particularly crucial in the Arctic, where rapid sea ice loss is likely to make the ocean seasonally navigable within decades56, increasing its importance for human activities and the urgency of understanding its changing environment.MethodsModel and data descriptionThe dataset used in this study was obtained from the ultra-high-resolution idealized greenhouse warming experiments conducted with fully coupled CESM-UHR32,33,34. The model has very high horizontal resolutions of 0.25° and 0.1° for the atmosphere and ocean components, respectively. This capability enables the model to resolve mesoscale dynamical processes in large parts of the oceans, such as eddies, meanders, fronts, filaments and so on.The CESM-UHR experiments include a present-day control run (PD) and two idealized experiments with CO2 doubling and quadrupling conditions (2 × CO2 and 4 × CO2)34,35,36,37. The PD simulation was integrated for 140 years from a quasi-equilibrated climate state33 with a CO2 concentration of 367 ppm. The 2 × CO2 (734 ppm) and 4 × CO2 (1,468 ppm) experiments were integrated for 100 years each (model year 71–170) after they split from year 71 of the PD experiment. The last quasi-equilibrated 10 years, excluding the final year for each simulation, are analysed to avoid climate drifts. The final year was partly used for Lagrangian tracking. The analysis period is from 1 January 130 to 31 December 139 of model year (10 years) for the PD simulation and from 1 January 160 to 31 December 169 of model year (10 years) for both the 2 × CO2 and 4 × CO2 simulations.To quantify the MHS at the surface ocean, we use daily mean \(u\) and \(v\) velocity fields at the second layer of the ocean model component of the CESM, Parallel Ocean Program v.2 (POP2)57, which corresponds to a depth of 10–20 m and has a central depth of 15 m. This study also analyses daily surface ocean current speed of the same layer and surface wind stress from POP2 and the sea ice model component of the CESM, Community Ice CodE v.4 (CICE4)58.Finite-size Lyapunov exponentThe FSLE is a powerful Lagrangian diagnostic and used to quantify the rate of separation caused by horizontal stirring28. Considering two particles in a turbulent fluid, initially separated by a distance δ0 and moving along distinct trajectories, we can model the growth of their separation δ(t) using the continuous exponential growth equation:$$\delta \left(t\right)={\delta }_{0}\,{{\rm{e}}}^{\lambda t},$$
                    (1)
                where the growth rate (\(\lambda\)) is the Lyapunov exponent59. The FSLE is a way to compute \(\lambda\) by explicitly defining spatial scales. The calculation begins by defining two scale factors of the initial and final distances (δ0, δf) between the two particles as finite values. Then, by using the Lagrangian tracking, we follow the movement of the two particles along the \(u\), \(v\) fields and calculate the FSLEs on the basis of the time \(\tau\) for δ(t) to evolve from δ0 to δf:$$\lambda (x,y,t,{\delta }_{\mathrm{0}},{\delta }_{\mathrm{f}})=\frac{1}{\tau }\mathrm{ln}\frac{{\delta }_{\mathrm{f}}}{{\delta }_{\mathrm{0}}}.$$
                    (2)
                This calculation is performed using the open-source Python program lagrangian 2.2.0 and the FSLE is determined by the maximum eigenvalue of the Cauchy–Green strain tensor, which is technically obtained through the Triplet method using three positional points (see section for ‘Code availability’).Since we are interested in mesoscale processes in the surface ocean, we computed the two-dimensional daily FSLE fields with δ0 and δf set to 0.1° and 1.0° (approximately 10 km and 110 km), respectively. To obtain the FSLEs for a single day at 12:00:00 UTC, the trajectories of the particles are integrated using the fourth-order Runge–Kutta method with constant 24-h intervals for a maximum of 360 days. If δ(t) is less than δf during the 360-day integration period, \(\lambda\) exists within the range of 0 and \({\lambda }_{360}\) (\({\lambda }_{360}\) is \(\lambda\) when \(\tau =360\) days). While other studies typically assume \(\lambda =0\) in this case, we assume \(\lambda ={\lambda }_{360}\) to avoid underestimation (Supplementary Fig. 4). The difference in results between the two assumptions—0 or \({\lambda }_{360}\)—is negligible, because \({\lambda }_{360}=\,\frac{1}{360}\mathrm{ln}10\approx 6.40\times {10}^{-3}\), which is close to zero.The FSLE technique can also be used to detect the Lagrangian coherent structures (LCSs)3,13,60 as well as the separation rate. LCSs can be categorized as either repelling or attracting based on the direction of trajectory integration used to calculate the FSLE. The forward-in-time FSLE integration identifies repelling LCSs (stable manifolds), while the backward-in-time integration reveals attracting LCSs (unstable manifolds). Although this study uses the forward-in-time FSLE calculations, it does not explicitly analyse LCSs. We focus solely on the separation rate of trajectories to quantify horizontal stirring. In this context, the choice between forward-in-time and backward-in-time FSLE makes no substantial difference28.Harmonic mean of FSLEsWhile previous studies have generally used the arithmetic mean, \(\bar{\lambda }\) (\(=\frac{1}{n}{\sum }_{i=1}^{n}{\lambda }_{i}\)), of the estimated FSLEs for temporal or spatial averaging, we primarily use the harmonic mean, \({\bar{\lambda }}_{{\mathrm{h}}}\) (\(=n/{\sum }_{i=1}^{n}\frac{1}{{\lambda }_{i}}\)), as it is more appropriate for averaging rates of increase (exponents). The two averaging methods produce different FSLE patterns (Supplementary Fig. 5), with the harmonic mean giving greater weight to smaller FSLE values than the arithmetic mean. Nevertheless, our overall conclusions are insensitive to the choice of averaging method.Computation of mean, eddy and total kinetic energyTo focus on the effects of oceanic mesoscale dynamics, we apply a 300-day high-pass filter43 to the \(u\) and \(v\) outputs of CESM-UHR simulations at 15-m depth to obtain the eddies (\({u}^{{\prime} }\), \({v}^{{\prime} }\)) (‘Code availability’). The mean flow (\(\bar{u}\), \(\bar{v}\)) is then obtained by subtracting \({u}^{{\prime} }\), \({v}^{{\prime} }\) from \(u\), \(v\). Here the 300-day cutoff approximately separates seasonal and longer-period variations into the mean flow. Subsequently, MKE, EKE and TKE are calculated using the following equations:$$\mathrm{MKE}=0.5({\bar{u}}^{2}+{\bar{v}}^{2}),$$
                    (3)
                $$\mathrm{EKE}=0.5({{u}^{{\prime} }}^{2}+{{v}^{{\prime} }}^{2}),$$
                    (4)
                $$\mathrm{TKE}=\mathrm{MKE}+\mathrm{EKE}.$$
                    (5)
                Wind stress scaling in the presence of sea iceWhen sea ice fraction (A) is not considered in the wind stress partitioning equation,$${\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{ocn}}=\left(1-A\right){\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{ao}}+A{\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{io}},$$
                    (6)
                the magnitude of two terms on the right-hand side can be roughly scaled from the quadratic drag law46:$${\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{ao}}={\rho }_{\mathrm{a}}{C}_{\mathrm{Da}}\left|{\vec{u}}_{\mathrm{a}}\right|{\vec{u}}_{\mathrm{a}}\,\left(\approx {10}^{0}\times 0.00125\times {10}^{0}\times {10}^{0}\approx 0.00125\right),$$
                    (7)
                $${\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{io}}=\rho {C}_{\mathrm{Di}}\left|{\vec{u}}_{\mathrm{rel}}\right|{\vec{u}}_{\mathrm{rel}}\,\left(\approx {10}^{3}\times 0.0055\times {10}^{-2}\times {10}^{-2}\approx 0.00055\right).$$
                    (8)
                Here the water density \(\rho\) is approximately 1,000 times greater than the air density \({\rho }_{\mathrm{a}}\): \(\rho /{\rho }_{\mathrm{a}}={\mathscr{O}}\left({10}^{3}\right)\). Additionally, the relative velocity between the sea ice and ocean current \({\vec{u}}_{\mathrm{rel}}\) (a few cm s−1) is about 0.01 of the surface wind velocity \({\vec{u}}_{\mathrm{a}}\) (a few m s−1): \(\left|{\vec{u}}_{\mathrm{rel}}\right|/\left|{\vec{u}}_{\mathrm{a}}\right|={\mathscr{O}}\left({10}^{-2}\right)\). The drag coefficients for the air–ocean CDa and ice–ocean CDi are 0.00125 and 0.0055, respectively. From the rough scaling of magnitude, \({\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{io}}\) is about 0.44 times of \({\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{ao}}\).

Data availability
            
            The model data (CESM-UHR) used to produce the paper figures are available at https://ibsclimate.org/research/ultra-high-resolution-climate-simulation-project/. The ocean reanalysis data (GLORYS12) are available at https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00021. The model output used to generate the figures in this study is available via Zenodo at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.17120099 (ref. 61). Source data are provided with this paper.
          Code availability
            
            The open-source Python program (lagrangian 2.2.0) to calculate the FSLE is available at https://lagrangian.readthedocs.io/en/stable/. The FSLE calculation workflow, EKE calculation, visualization scripts and data analysis codes are available via Zenodo at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.16976589 (ref. 62).
